moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6: The starting position for all the games.
moves.9. c3 Ne7 10. d4: The point of the variation: if Black now exchanges Pawns, White is left with an "ideal center".
moves.10... Nxd5 11. dxc5 Nf4 12. g3 Ne6 13. c: If Black now replies PxP I can use the half open Q file to pressure the backward QP.
moves.14... cxd6 15. O-O-O: With the Queens gone, I'm not afraid to leave my King in a relatively open area.
moves.16... Rd8 17. Bb3: I don't want my B to remain loose, plus I add protection to the QR in case of a potential future exchange.
moves.17... b5 18. Kb1: The struggle for a tempo. Neither side can do a whole lot that is productive, and I start thinking in terms of a draw.
moves.18... Bb7 19. Bc2: Adding a guard to the KP.
moves.19... Rac8 20. h4: Preventing a potential K-side surge. To use a Niemzowitschian phrase, i'm reducing the game's dynamism.
moves.20... a5 21. Nd2: Clearing a space, eventually, for my KB pawn to secure the K pawn.
moves.21... f6 22. Nf1: Opening the line back up to keep the pressure on the Q pawn.
moves.23... Rdc8 24. f3: ...so that I can finally secure my KP solidly.
moves.24... b4 25. Rdd3: Starting to wind the game down.
moves.25... Nc5 26. Rd1: Discretion is the only part of valor here.
moves.26... bxc3 27. Rxc3: Offering to drain more energy out of the game...
moves.29... Nd7 30. Bd3: Draw agreed. After 30...BxB 31 RxB the QBP is guarded and the Rook and Knight ending offers no real winning chances to either side.
